ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: learned a lot about different saints and relics as well as how to think about these types of artworks.

I learned about art inspired by the lives of early Christians and medieval people. I did not have much background in the history of Christianity, nor art history, but I felt welcomed in every discussion and it was not intimidating to participate. I feel that I have gained excitement for the diverse forms of art around this topic; a foundation for sharing with family and friends; and eagerness to travel to some of the sites we virtually visited!

I learned about some of the most influential saints of the Middle Ages and the devotional traditions associated with each. I also gained an appreciation for the ways in which these saints have been venerated in reliquaries and portrayed in art across the ages. The final paper gave us an opportunity to explore some of these questions in more depth and practice making use of secondary scholarship to develop our own analysis.
We learned about different types of reliquaries and European medieval saints. Our discussions included topics of race and gender in the Middle Ages, as well as looking at art objects.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked the rhythm of the class, but I do think it would function better in an in-person environment. Sometimes it was difficult to follow which part of a piece we were discussing because we couldn't point like in person.

There are no weaknesses I can think of. Professor Jung's insights and enthusiasm are an obvious strength. I also appreciated all of our live seminar discussions. The final project was a great opportunity to synthesize what I learned.

This class had many strengths. All of the readings, both primary and secondary, were very interesting and engaging. The balance between primary/secondary and visual/textual sources was also well-designed. It was great to scroll through the Beinecke digital archives and speak with one of the authors of an article we had read in class. The discussion board posts were also productive, ging us a chance to reflect in depth on the week's readings before discussing them together. My only suggestion is very minor: I think I would have preferred the class to meet twice weekly for shorter periods of time instead of only once a week, so that we could discuss more regularly throughout the week.
Strengths: multiple modes of engagement with material (creative and academic), varied readings, open-ended final project

This course was amazing! It was so great to learn from Professor Jung's expertise, especially in the class on St Maurice, since she has done so much cool scholarship on that topic. I wish we could have had more back and forth discussion between students during class, but that was very hard due to zoom.

Strengths: Professor Jung is a captivating teacher and her knowledge of the topic is incredible. The texts, though complex, are highly engaging and sparked a high level of discussion in the classroom. 
Weaknesses: I would have preferred to have two medium-sized assignments spread out throughout the semester than have one assignment due at the end of the semester be worth 50% of my grade.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought this course was organized as well as possible for COVID.
I have not participated in many seminars, but I felt that the online format worked fine for our discussions.
All COVID-19 practices were helpful, including the discussion board format and Zoom office hours. Also very amenable to hosting our guest speaker from CO!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! It's a great art history course for those interested in religion and/or medieval art.
Yes, definitely! This was my favorite class in college. It challenged me to think about my own faith, and introduced me to an awesome body of art and art historical perspectives.

Yes, this was a fascinating course and offers important insight into the devotional culture of medieval Europe. The classroom environment was supportive and welcoming to students of all backgrounds and perspectives. The objects under investigation are truly breathtaking and tell such important stories about the early Christian world that students come to understand and articulate for themselves over the course of the semester.

Yes--it is so interesting, and Professor Jung is wonderful. The world of medieval art is so colorful and exciting. The course gave me a lot of practice with visual analysis and working through different kinds of readings. Professor Jung is so enthusiastic about medieval art that it's infectious.
Yes, definitely! This is a must for anyone interested in medieval art.
Yes, if you are interested in medieval art and religion, you should definitely take this course. Professor Jung is an expert on the subject and we had fascinating classroom discussions.
Definitely. This was a wonderful class and Professor Jung is an absolute pleasure to work with.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Occasionally, we used the discussion board to record reflections from readings.
